paragraph.paragraph:
The Object Browser allows you to browse the objects available for use in your system. You may only browse the objects of a compiled system that is currently open in Visual Studio. Aswell as being able to view available objects, the object browser allows you to see the
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel feature>features of each object and the relationships between objects, for example,
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel ancestors>ancestors .

Looking at the screenshot, you can see that there is one root node in the object browser, which corresponds to the fact that there is only one project, named "sample", in the currentlyopened solution. If there is more than one project in the current solution, then there will be multiple entries in the tree.
The object browser has three main areas:

list.item:
Objects - Situated at the top left hand side of the object browser, this pane allows you to browse the objects in the system, their
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel feature>features and any
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel ancestors>ancestors . Selecting an object in this pane will display the features defined in this object only in the Memberspane, and to see all the features available for the object, select the all features node.

Members - Situated at the top right hand side of the object browser, this pane displays the current members of the selected item in the Objects pane. Certain selections, such asancestors, have no members, as the information is displayed in the Objects pane when the node is expanded.

Description - Pertinent information regarding the selected item in the Objects pane or Members pane will be displayed in this pane. For some selections, this pane may be empty, asthere will be no information on the currently selected node.

paragraph.paragraph: The toolbar at the very top of the object browser allows you to modify the information displayed.

Double clicking an Eiffel class or a feature in the object browser will automatically open up its definition in the
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel Editor>Editor .

Right clicking on any node in the class view will display a
context_menu.xml context menu for the current node.

For details of the hierarchy displayed in the Object Browser, click
hierarchy.xml here .
